author: protolambda
content:
<@!372731338031366165> about eth2stats, what's out there to set up:
- dashboard. I forked it so it builds on github pages (with github action), so it doesn't require the old nginx setup, and you can reference external dashboards in header + be clear about git fork info. You can fork https://github.com/protolambda/pyrmont.eth2.wtf for the latest styling/fixes, and a working config as example. I still need to merge those changes back into my open PR here: https://github.com/ConsenSys/eth2stats-dashboard/pull/1 There is a config file to define server endpoint, linked dashboards and fork info. And there is a CNAME file to configure the domain. You can also run it locally (use npm commands for hot-reloads etc.), and point it to a local server instead by using an environment var.
- client: works as-is, hosted on https://github.com/Alethio/eth2stats-client (you can use upstream docker image)
- server: collects clients metrics, and exposes a grpc (for client input) and http (for dashboard serving) endpoint. The websocket is available via upgrade on that same http ednpoint, but was always was a WIP, and doesn't actually do anything but connecting (not my idea). My fork has a branch with some experimental fixes and geo-ip update.

author: sky.cactus
content: If I voluntary exit, I know I cannot withdraw my ETH back to ETH1.  However, can I re-enter as a validator?

author: sky.cactus
content: For example, if I know I won't be able to run my validator for a couple months (for reasons), can I voluntarily exit and then voluntarily enter a couple months later?

author: sproul
content: No, voluntary exits are currently irreversible

author: sproul
content: You'd have to either take the hit for being offline, or find another way to keep validating

author: sky.cactus
content: Is there a mechanism design reason for this, or just engineering cost/complexity that we wanted to avoid in phase 0?

author: nishant0
content: Mostly the latter, having the ability for exited validators to be active again would add more complexity around the handling of validator indexes. Let me see if i can link the conversation
